summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Paul A. Engelmayer requesting an extension of deadlines in a FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times Company against the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The lawsuit seeks records related to Jeffrey Epstein. The BOP needs more time to review over 2,500 pages of records from the OIG and coordinate with other DOJ components.

persons.name: Paul A. Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge over the FOIA case The New York Times Co. v. Federal Bureau of Prisons. He grants the extension request.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signs the letter on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office representing the defendant, the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The FOIA lawsuit seeks records related to him. The letter specifies that email review will focus on emails sent to or from Epstein while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

connections.description: Strauss's office represents the BOP as defendant in the FOIA lawsuit.
Engelmayer is the presiding judge in the FOIA case brought by The New York Times Company.
The BOP held Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, and the FOIA request seeks records related to his time in custody.

keyFacts: The Federal Bureau of Prisons is involved in a FOIA lawsuit with The New York Times Company seeking records related to Jeffrey Epstein.
Over 2,500 pages of records from the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) remain to be reviewed by the BOP and other DOJ components.
The email review will be limited to emails sent to or from Jeffrey Epstein himself during his time at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
This was the BOP's sixth overall request to extend or stay the summary judgment schedule in this case.
Judge Paul A. Engelmayer granted the extension but indicated no further extensions would be granted absent extraordinary circumstances.
